text: <@U016535QCJ2> what do you mean by your model "only uses a few arbitrary thresholds"? Surprised your thresholds are arbitrary and not set empirically?

elements.text: what do you mean by your model "only uses a few arbitrary thresholds"? Surprised your thresholds are arbitrary and not set empirically?

text: Two obvious ones come to mind that can't be set empirically. Looking at starting price and setting a threshold beyond which I don't think the price is accurate enough (using market percentages). I do statistics and use samples for each point - I have to choose a number where I don't think I have enough samples for it to be accurate

elements.text: Two obvious ones come to mind that can't be set empirically. I do statistics and use samples for each point - I have to choose a number where I don't think I have enough samples for it to be accurate

text: Neither can be measured directly, because the outputs are the model, and you shouldn't set a threshold just to get better results from the model (neither give anything like linear results as I change thresholds, and the "noise" is significant)

text:
I am reading the back bet odds/size with the following..
price_filter = betfairlightweight.filters.price_projection(price_data=['EX_BEST_OFFERS'])
market_books = trading.betting.list_market_book(market_ids=[mk_id],price_projection=price_filter)
...and I see the set of three back prices just like on the exchange website. Early in the
morning the best back price available may be stable for many minutes on end (maybe even longer).
However when I actually programatically place an order with trading.betting.place_orders, I
very often find that I succeed in getting an even better price. Why might that be?

elements.text:
I am reading the back bet odds/size with the following..
price_filter = betfairlightweight.filters.price_projection(price_data=['EX_BEST_OFFERS'])
market_books = trading.betting.list_market_book(market_ids=[mk_id],price_projection=price_filter)
...and I see the set of three back prices just like on the exchange website. Early in the
morning the best back price available may be stable for many minutes on end (maybe even longer).
However when I actually programatically place an order with trading.betting.place_orders, I
very often find that I succeed in getting an even better price. Why might that be?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: what CS did you teach? What has been the most useful for betting?

text: I taught programming basics to math people at uni, and I can tell you they were better at CS than most of the CS undergrads :slightly_smiling_face: nothing related to betting.. in general the part about testingtestingtestingJUSTTESTYOURSTUFF was were they lacked the most

elements.text: I taught programming basics to math people at uni, and I can tell you they were better at CS than most of the CS undergrads
nothing related to betting.. in general the part about testingtestingtestingJUSTTESTYOURSTUFF was were they lacked the most

text: For betting, heh some applied ML and numerical approximation methods i think they are the best

text: (applied ML also include really doing it, as in clean your data, look at errors, etc etc..)

elements.text: (applied ML also include really doing it, as in clean your data, look at errors, etc etc..)

text: What I love about folk who want to do datascience is that they're generally obsessed with complex models and hitting the .fit() method on tensor flow, when actually spending time making sure your data is clean and working on sensible features is 95%+ of the job...

elements.text: What I love about folk who want to do datascience is that they're generally obsessed with complex models and hitting the .fit() method on tensor flow, when actually spending time making sure your data is clean and working on sensible features is 95%+ of the job...

text: (That said... I've spent the past few days working on an inference problem, so maybe I'm full of shit?)

elements.text: (That said... I've spent the past few days working on an inference problem, so maybe I'm full of shit?)

text: I spend a huge part of my time "cleaning" data, and another huge part of my time just looking at it by running query after query. I have several data sets for different purposes (historically sourced data, live collected data, etc) and it's all in databases on SQL server. I have probably run an average of 100 hand-crafted queries per day for the last 3 months on my data. My view is that you really really need to understand your data. The longer I go the more insights I get from the data. Also remember I use absolutely no ML (my partner working on his model does)

elements.text: I spend a huge part of my time "cleaning" data, and another huge part of my time just looking at it by running query after query. I have several data sets for different purposes (historically sourced data, live collected data, etc) and it's all in databases on SQL server. I have probably run an average of 100 hand-crafted queries per day for the last 3 months on my data. My view is that you really really need to understand your data. The longer I go the more insights I get from the data. Also remember I use absolutely no ML (my partner working on his model does)

text:
Funny how we all approach the game differently, for me it’s all about taking a simple idea and getting in the market with real money. See what works and what doesn’t, iterate to maximise profit/matching and move on.

I think the longest I have spent on making a model was a day (I get bored very quickly developing strategies) but that was only because I was crunching a few years of inplay data.

elements.text: Funny how we all approach the game differently, for me it’s all about taking a simple idea and getting in the market with real money. See what works and what doesn’t, iterate to maximise profit/matching and move on.
I think the longest I have spent on making a model was a day (I get bored very quickly developing strategies) but that was only because I was crunching a few years of inplay data.
